title: Up, Up, and Away
descriptions:
Up, Up, and Away (2000) is a family-friendly superhero adventure about a boy born into an extraordinary family who must find the courage to be a hero in his own way. The story centers on the Aarons, a loving suburban family whose members are all superheroes with various powers—invulnerability, flight, super strength, and more—operating under the family name the Steel Condors. They live quietly with secret identities, helping people discreetly and teaching their children strict rules about responsibility and the importance of using powers for good.

The youngest son, Scott Marshall, is turning 14, the age when members of his family typically "receive" their powers. He’s excited and anxious, eager to join the family legacy. His father, Bronze Eagle, and mother, Warrior Woman, lovingly push him to prepare for the big moment, and his grandparents—both seasoned heroes—share stories about their first rescues. At school, Scott tries to blend in with his friends, particularly his best friend Randy, who idolizes superheroes from afar without knowing Scott’s secret background. The pressure builds as Scott’s birthday approaches, and the entire family anticipates his powers arriving right on schedule.

But there’s a problem: Scott doesn’t have any powers. He tries to fake it at first—staging small “feats” to make his family proud and to avoid disappointing them. Every attempt becomes a comic mishap, especially when his relatives show off their abilities without thinking about how that makes Scott feel. Despite their warmth, he feels left out and worries he’ll never measure up.

Meanwhile, a philanthropic tech company called Earth Protectors arrives at Scott’s school with a program that seems too good to be true: a mission to help the environment through computer education modules and youth activism. The charismatic leader’s message impresses teachers and students alike, and the group begins distributing sleek educational CDs that promise to make kids more eco-conscious and involved in community change. Scott’s class, including Randy, embraces the program enthusiastically.

As the Earth Protectors’ influence grows, strange behavior follows. Students become unnaturally obedient and easily swayed, and adults who interact with the group begin parroting their talking points. Scott suspects something is off when Randy starts acting like a zombie-like super volunteer, and some of the town’s leaders adopt extreme new initiatives after a single demonstration. Scott eventually discovers that the Earth Protectors’ software uses a form of subliminal mind control to manipulate users, turning them into docile followers who will unwittingly enable a bigger scheme: neutralizing and capturing superheroes.

The company’s real target is the Steel Condors and others like them. The villains have developed a system that can trace superpowered activity and plan to exploit the town’s new environmental efforts as cover for a mass entrapment. When the family looks into the Earth Protectors, they’re cautious but underestimate the threat, believing their powers can handle anything. During a staged “community appreciation” event, the Earth Protectors spring their trap using specially tuned devices that weaken or immobilize superhumans, capturing Scott’s parents and grandparents.

With his family detained and the town increasingly under the organization’s sway, Scott faces a crisis. He has no powers to fall back on, and his earlier lies have left him embarrassed. But he refuses to give up. Drawing on what he’s learned from his family—strategy, compassion, and responsibility—as well as his own ingenuity, he decides to fight back using his strengths: quick thinking, loyalty, and knowledge of his family’s routines.

Scott confides in Randy, eventually breaking the superhero secrecy code just enough to get his friend’s help. Randy, who had been influenced by the Earth Protectors’ software, shakes off the mental fog with Scott’s support. Together, they investigate the company’s headquarters and uncover the device frequencies used to control people and dampen powers. Using an improvised plan that relies on timing rather than super strength, Scott and Randy infiltrate the facility. Scott evades detection with clever distractions, posing as a compliant participant to gain access, then slipping into restricted areas where his parents are held.

Inside, Scott locates the control hub, guarded by the project’s lead technologist, who boasts about reshaping society by eliminating the unpredictability of heroes. Scott stalls for time, reworks the equipment, and triggers a system glitch that shuts down the dampening fields long enough for his family to recover. The Steel Condors break free and reclaim their abilities just as security closes in. In the chaos, Scott coordinates escape routes, guiding his family to safety and using the knowledge he gathered to help them disable the remaining mind-control nodes without harming the enthralled civilians.

The climax pits the Aarons family against the Earth Protectors’ leadership, with Scott playing a crucial role.
